title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
4 points maximum

1 point can be earned for each of the first two appropriate descriptions of environmental problems of water diversion (additional descriptions are not scored); 1 point can be earned for a discussion of each of the environmental problems previously described.
descriptions:
Student response earns none of the available points.

4 points maximum

1 point can be earned for each of the first two appropriate descriptions of environmental problems of water diversion (additional descriptions are not scored); 1 point can be earned for a discussion of each of the environmental problems previously described.

Student response earns one of the available points.

Student response earns two of the available points.

Student response earns three of the available points.

1 point can be earned for each of the first two appropriate descriptions of environmental problems of water diversion (additional descriptions are not scored); 1 point can be earned for a discussion of each of the environmental problems previously described.

Student response earns four of the available points.

1 point can be earned for each of the first two appropriate descriptions of environmental problems of water diversion (additional descriptions are not scored); 1 point can be earned for a discussion of each of the environmental problems previously described.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
4 points maximum

1 point earned for the argument and 1 point for additional support of the argument. Maximum of 2 points for urban areas and 2 points for natural areas.

Definition of “argument” used: “A coherent series of statements leading from a premise to a conclusion” (Merriam Webster, 2002)

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
3 points maximum

1 point is earned by identifying another water diversion project. 1 point is earned for each environmental problem that might result from the project (maximum of two points). Students must identify a specific water diversion project in order to earn one or all three points. They cannot earn the discussion points unless they have identified a diversion project. Since the question wording (“other than the Colorado River”) might direct the student to focus on the name of a specific river and state their answer such as, “the damming of the Nile River”, this type of response earns the identification point.

The two environmental problems discussed must be applicable to the identified water diversion project, and only the first two problems discussed are scored.

Water Diversion Projects (some examples are shown below; although this is not a comprehensive list):

Many environmental problems listed in part (a) may be used in the discussion for this part. There are also some unique environmental problems associated with specific projects that would also be acceptable.

Example of discussion for James Bay (Hydropower)

Hydro-Quebec (1970s) diverted rivers flowing into the James Bay flooding more than 4,000 square miles of tundra and coastal wetlands along the eastern shore of the Hudson Bay. The project will consist of 600 dams, dikes and will block 19 large rivers and create other diversions.

Adverse impacts: 10,000 caribou were drowned in 1984 while migrating; threat of mercury poisoning to native peoples (Cree) on newly flooded land — 66 percent of residents had high levels as per WHO standards; coastal marshes and estuaries were degraded (eel grass already disappeared and is a keystone species); salmon and other anadromous fish were blocked from spawning beds.
